title-group.article-title: Self-Reported Inattention in Early Adolescence in a Community Sample

author-notes.corresp: Maggie E. Toplak, 126 BSB, Departmalest of Psychology, York University, 4700 Keele St., Toronto, Ontario, Canada M3J 1P3 Email: mtoplak@yorku.ca

fn.p: Laura L. Connors is a doctoral candidate of the clinical-developmalestal program in psychology at York University. She is a student member of the LaMarsh Center for Research on Violence and Conflict Resolution. Her research interests include the developmalest of ADHD and other developmalestal psychopathologies.

Jennifer Connolly is a full professor of the clinical-developmalestal program in psychology at York University. She is also the director of the LaMarsh Center for Research on Violence and Conflict Resolution. Her research interests include psychosocial developmalest in childhood and adolescence, with a particular interest in the developmalest of romantic relationships.

Maggie E. Toplak is an associate professor of the clinical-developmalestal program in psychology at York University. She is a core member of the LaMarsh Centre for Research on Violence and Conflict Resolution. Her research interests include applying cognitive models in understanding developmalestal psychopathology, with a particular emphasis on ADHD.

abstract.p: Objective : Inattention is typically associated with ADHD, but less research has been done to examine the correlates of self-reported inattention in youth in a community sample. Method: Associations among self-reported inattention, parent-reported inattention, and self-reported psychopathology in children aged 10 to 11 years are examined. Self-reported inattention is also examined as a predictor of outcomes in peer relationships and victimization at ages 10 and 11 and in peer relationships at ages 14 and 15. Results: Children’s self-reports of inattention correlate with parental reports and are associated with self-reports of hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct problems. Participants in the high-inattention group are at greater risk for victimization and poor peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 years after covarying for psychopathology ratings. Self-reported inattention uniquely predicts poor peer relationships longitudinally at age 14 and 15 years. Conclusion: This study highlights the importance of examining children’s self-report of inattention and identifies inattention as a risk factor for current and later outcomes.

body.p: Inattention is increasingly recognized as a problem that affects both malestal and physical health (Burke, Loeber, & Lahey, 2001; Burke, Loeber, White, Stouthamer-Loeber, & Pardini, 2007; Neyens, & Boyle, 2007; Tercyak, Lerman, & Audrain, 2002). Inattention defines a set of behaviors, including distractibility, failure in sustained attention, and forgetfulness (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Malestal Disorders, 4th edition, Text Revision; DSM-IV-TR; American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2000). In one self-report study spanning 24 countries, distractability was one of the most common problems reported by adolescents in general population, nonclinical samples (Rescorla et al., 2007). Inattentive symptoms have also been associated with executive dysfunction (Chhabildas, Pennington, & Willcutt, 2001; Nigg et al., 2005). Inattention has been typically linked with the diagnosis of ADHD (DSM-IV-TR, APA, 2000). Some have argued that inattention in ADHD is uniquely important from the hyperactive and impulsive symptoms of ADHD (Diamond, 2005). Developmalest may also be an important consideration in the study of inattention, as it has been noted that that the hyperactivity and impulsivity may decrease during the developmalestal transition into adolescence, whereas inattention may increase (Robin, 1998).

The purpose of this research was to investigate self-reported inattention in a community sample of youth aged 10 to 11 years. Inattention has traditionally only been regarded within the context of ADHD and has rarely been studied separately from the hyperactivity and impulsivity combined types (having a combination of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity) of ADHD. Also, very little research has examined correlates of self-reported inattention and longitudinal follow-up studies (Barkley, 2006). We suggest that inattention should be examined on a continuum to better understand normative and clinical levels of attention, as has been done in the depression literature (Compas, Ey, & Grant, 1993). Use of a community sample permits such continuous analyses, and thus, inattention was treated as a dimalessional construct (Kraemer, 2007) in the current study. This research contributes to our understanding of whether self-reported inattention in youth is a significant risk factor in developmalest. The main goal of this study was to examine self-reported inattention in a community sample as a risk factor for predicting outcomes in victimization and peer relationships in youth aged 10 and 11 and in peer relationships longitudinally when youth were aged between 14 and 15 years. Associations among self-reported inattention, parent-reported inattention, and self-reported psychopathology in children aged 10 to 11 years were also examined.

sec.title: Inattention as a Risk Factor for Psychosocial Maladjustmalest
sec.p: Children with ADHD reportedly have more comorbid conditions, such as anxiety, depression, and conduct problems (Barkley, 2006). However, inattention is commonly associated with other childhood psychopathologies, such as anxiety and depression (DSM-IV-TR, APA, 2000). In an epidemiological study, self-reported inattention was found to be correlated with self-reports of conduct disorder, anxiety, and depression for adolescent boys and girls (Schaughency, McGee, Nada Raja, Feehan, & Silva, 1994). Although there is a body of work to suggest associations between inattention and psychopathology, the unique contributions of inattention to youth problems have received little attention.

Inattention has traditionally been examined in conjunction with hyperactivity-impulsivity in the diagnosis of ADHD, but there is limited work examining negative outcomes for inattention alone. Wheeler Maedgen and Carlson (2000) compared children with ADHD Combined Subtype (ADHD-C) and children with ADHD Predominantly Inattentive Subtype (ADHD-I) in psychosocial functioning. The authors reported that along with the ADHD-C children, the predominantly inattentive children also experienced difficulties in social functioning in comparison to controls. However, the nature of difficulty differed depending on ADHD subtype. The children with ADHD-C showed more aggressive behavior and emotional dysregulation, whereas the children with ADHD-I displayed social passivity and deficits in social knowledge, but did not show the problems in emotional regulation. These types of studies illustrate the challenge of examining the unique contribution of inattention in the study of ADHD, as most samples are composed of children with inattention and combined inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity. Studies with community samples provide an opportunity to understand the unique contributions of inattention.

Studies in community samples have shown that inattention has been linked to problem behavior (Bellanti, Bierman, & the Conduct Problems Prevention Research Group, 2000; Hill, Degnan, Calkins, & Keane, 2006). One longitudinal study examining early problems of inattention found that inattention at age 2 predicted membership in a chronic clinical profile, such as externalizing behaviors, for both boys and girls (Hill et al., 2006). Another study reported that inattention was found to predict aggressive and prosocial behavior, such that inattention was associated with increased rates of disruptive and aggressive behavior and deficits in social skills. The inattentive group was also reported to be significantly less well liked by peers than the nonproblem comparison group (Bellanti et al., 2000). In the current study, we examined whether self-reported inattention would be uniquely associated with peer relationship problems at ages 10 to 11 and longitudinally at ages 14 to 15 in a community sample of 10- to 11-year-old children.

sec.title: Gender
sec.p: Developmalestally, it has been shown that females tend to report more internalizing symptoms whereas males tend to report more externalizing symptoms (Rescorla et al., 2007). Studies from ADHD studies suggest that females with inattention may be at higher risk than males. Females with ADHD have been shown to report more depression, anxiety, and distress than do females in the control group or males with ADHD (Rucklidge & Tannock, 2001). Females with inattention and hyperactivity have also been reported as being at higher risk for smoking and alcohol use than are males (Galera, Fombonne, Chastang, & Bouvard, 2005; Whalen, Jamner, Henker, Delfino, & Lozano, 2002). Thus, we examined gender differences in self-reported inattention and other behavioral ratings in the current study.

sec.title: Self-Report and Inattention
sec.p: Conventionally, caregivers and teachers are typical informants for childhood behavior, as children’s reports have not been considered diagnostic (Bierman, 1983). This trend is particularly evident in ADHD. In contrast, more reliance is placed on child or adolescent report in internalizing disorders such as anxiety and depression (Loeber, Green, & Lahey, 1990). Children as young as 4 have been found to provide useful self-reports on basic symptoms of internalizing problems such as anxiety and depression (Luby, Belden, Sullivan, & Spitznagel, 2007).

The use of multiple informants in the reporting of child and adolescent symptomology and behavior is endorsed clinically. This is evidenced by increased use of checklists and self-reports completed by older children and adolescents (W. M. Reynolds, 1993) and the availability of self-report scales for youth and children as young as age eight (e.g., Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001; Conners, 2008; C. R. Reynolds & Kamphaus, 2004). The psychometric data for these scales demonstrate significant moderate correlations between self- and parent-report scales. However, the demonstrated use and validity of child and adolescent self-report is debated, as the evidence with respect to concurrence between youth and parent report of behavior and symptoms has been mixed. Some research has shown that adolescent and parent reports often show minor agreemalest surrounding problem behavior (Jensen et al., 1999; Seiffge-Krenke & Kollmar, 1998). Other studies have reported that young adolescents report significantly more internalizing and externalizing symptoms than their parents (Rescorla et al., 2007; Seiffge-Krenke & Kollmar, 1998). Some studies have suggested a greater degree of concurrence between parent and youth reports, including a study of examining child, parent, and teacher report in a sample of 6- to 14-year-old children and adolescents with ADHD (Klimkeit et al., 2006), and between 15-year-old adolescents and parent reports of inattention in a community sample (Schaughency et al., 1994). Overall, mixed findings have been reported with respect to the degree of concurrence between parent and youth reports of inattention and hyperactivity symptoms. Differences have also been found in symptom reporting between males and females (Rescorla et al., 2007; Rucklidge & Tannock, 2001). Thus, self-report of inattention was examined in this study, in relation to other self-reported measures of behavior and psychosocial maladjustmalest.

In the current study, we examined whether self-reported inattention is a unique risk factor for both current outcomes of victimization and peer relationships and longitudinal outcomes in peer relationship problems 4 years later in a community sample. This study also examined the association between self-reported inattention with parent report and other self-reported behavior. It was expected that inattention would be a unique risk factor for victimization at ages 10 to 11, peer relationships at ages 10 to 11, and longitudinally in peer relationships 4 years later when youth were aged between 14 and 15 years. Females were hypothesized to demonstrate a stronger correlation between self-reported inattention and internalizing behavior ratings than were males. It was also expected that self-reported inattention would be significantly associated with parent-reported inattention.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The data analyzed were part of a national longitudinal study being conducted by Statistics Canada called the National Longitudinal Survey of Children and Youth (NLSCY). The NLSCY is a longitudinal study following the developmalest of Canadian children from birth to early adulthood. Information is collected on environmalestal, biological, economic, and social topics as well as risk and protective factors in developmalest. The current study focused on the self-complete portion (participants aged 10-17 answer questions about themselves) and included some variables from the adult portion (questions are asked to the “person most knowledgeable” [PMK] about the child).

Participants in the original cohort of the NLSCY were selected as part of the Statistics Canada Labour Force Survey (LFS). The LFS collects labor market data from approximately 54,000 dwellings in Canada. It is representative of civilian, noninstitutionalized population aged 15 and more in the 10 Canadian provinces. Sampling for the LFS was based on a stratified, multistage design employing probability sampling at all stages of the design. Stratification is determined through a multistep process consisting of dividing provinces into economic regions, type of area (e.g., remote, urban, rural), housing type (e.g., apartmalest or area frame), as well as by income when possible (Statistics Canada, 2006). The data used in the current analyses, therefore, represent a diverse and representative Canadian community sample.

Overall, data in the NLSCY are divided into six cycles, with the first cycle beginning in 1994 and sampling children aged 0 to 11 years. The survey was readministered every 2 years; thus, the sixth cycle was composed of children aged 10 to 21 years. In the current study, data from the fourth cycle (collected in 2000-2001) and the sixth cycle (collected in 2004-2005) were used. Participants who were between 10 and 11 years of age were selected as the target age group, as we were interested in their self-report of behavior and because parent ratings were also available for this age. These two cycles were selected to have a more powerful test of the longitudinal questions (4-year gap as opposed to a 2-year gap), and selection of these two cycles maximized sample size. The available data included 1,974 parent reports and 1,532 self-reports. The sample demographics at the fourth cycle were as follows: The mean age of the sample was 10.49 years (SD = .50), with males constituting 49.5% of the sample. The PMK was most often the biological mother (89.7%), of which 74.8% reported marital status as “married.” Then, 73.1% of the children lived with both biological parents, a biological mother and no father (13.8%), the biological mother and stepfather (7.5%), or some other arrangemalest (5.6%). Median family income ranged from Cdn$60,000 to Cdn$79,000.

sec.title: Inattention
sec.p: Inattention was measured using a composite composed of 3 items: “I am easily distracted”; “I can’t concentrate/can’t pay attention”; and “I am inattentive.” Each item was scored on a 3-point scale, where 1 = never or not true, 2 = sometimes or somewhat true, and 3 = often or always true. Interitem correlations ranged from .42 to .51 (p < .01). Table 1 displays the interitem correlations within the composite. An inattention score was calculated for each participant, on the basis of the mean value of the three inattention questions. A higher score indicated more inattention. A parent report of inattention composite was based on the same questionnaire items.

caption.p: List of Composites and Interitem Correlations

tr.td: 1. Easily distracted, has trouble sticking to any activity
2. Can’t concentrate, can’t pay attention for long
3. Have difficulty waiting for my turn
2. I am not as happy as other people
1. I am too fearful or nervous
3. I am nervous, high-strung, or tense
1. Other children say mean things to you
3. You are bullied going to school
2. I get along easily with others my age
3. Others my age want me to be a friend
4. Most others my age like me
2. I get along easily with others my age
3. Others my age want me to be a friend
4. Most others my age like me

sec.title: Other self-report behavior ratings
sec.p: Four composites were constructed on the basis of relevant behavioral items to obtain ratings of self reported hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct problems. The behavior-rating composites were measured in a manner similar to the measuremalest of the inattention composite. Higher scores indicated a stronger endorsemalest of hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct problems. Table 1 includes items and interitem correlations for each composite.

sec.title: Indices of psychosocial maladjustmalest
sec.p: Two composite indices of psychosocial maladjustmalest were examined, including a victimization composite at ages 10 and 11 and a quality of peer relationship composite at ages 10 and 11 and at ages 14 and 15. These were also self-report scales. The victimization composite consisted of 3 items, whereas the peer relationship composite had 4 items. A higher score on the victimization composite indicated a lower frequency of victimization. A higher score on the peer relationship composite indicated better peer relationships. Items and interitem correlations are listed in Table 1.

sec.title: Description of Inattention in a Community Sample
sec.p: Most analyses were conducted treating variables continuously. The self-reported inattention composite was split into three levels, including low-, moderate-, and high-inattention subgroups for some analyses.1 On the basis of these groupings, we found that 57% of participants were in the low-inattention group, 35% were in the moderate-inattention group, and 8% were in the high-inattention group. Furthermore, on the basis of parent reports of inattention, we found that 60% were in the low-inattention group, 29% were in the moderate-inattention group, and 11% were in the high-inattention group. In the case of self-reported inattention, when considering gender, we found that 52% of males and 61% of females were in the low-inattention group, 39% of males and 32% of females were in the moderate-inattention group, and 9% of males and 7% of females were in the high-inattention group. In the case of parent-reported inattention, we found that 53% of males and 67% of females were in low-inattention group, 31% of males and 26% of females were in the moderate-inattention group, and 16% of males and 7% females were in the high-inattention group. The means and standard deviations of self- and parent-reported inattention are presented in Table 2, by overall sample and separately by gender.

caption.p: Means and Standard Deviations of Levels of Inattention

sec.title: Inattention as a Risk Factor for Victimization and Quality of Peer Relationships at Ages 10 and 11
Victimization
sec.p: A 2- × 3-way ANCOVA was conducted with gender (male vs. female) and inattention level (low, moderate, high) as between-subject independent variables and self-reported victimization as the dependent variable. Self-reported hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct-problem ratings were entered as covariates. There was a significant main effect of inattention group, F(2, 1,126) = 8.82, p < .001, such that the participants with high self-reported inattention reported more victimization than did participants who reported low or moderate levels of inattention. There was also a significant main effect of gender, F(1, 1,126) = 10.37, p = .001, such that males reported experiencing more victimization than females did. The interaction between inattention and gender was not significant. When covariates were examined, self-reported depression, F(1, 1,126) = 41.82, p < .001; anxiety, F(1, 1,126) = 14.79, p < .001; and conduct problem, F(1, 1,126) = 37.04, p < .001, ratings emerged as significant covariates, but inattention and gender remained significant predictors.

sec.title: Peer relationships
sec.p: A 2 × 3 ANCOVA was conducted with gender and inattention level as independent variables and perceived quality of peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 as the dependent variable. Self-reported hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct-problem ratings were entered as covariates. There was a significant main effect of inattention, F(2, 1,139) = 10.91, p <.001, such that participants with high inattention reported poorer peer relationships than did participants with moderate or low levels of inattention. There was also a significant main effect of gender, F(1, 1,139) = 10.49, p = .001, such that males reported poorer peer relationships than females did. The interaction between inattention and gender was not significant. When covariates were examined, depression, F(1, 1,139) = 32.00, p < .001, and conduct problem, F(1, 1,139) = 3.79, p = .05, ratings were significant covariates, but inattention and gender remained significant.

A 2 × 3 ANCOVA was conducted with gender and inattention level as independent variables and perceived quality of peer relationships at ages 14 and 15 as the dependent variable. Self-reported hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct-problem ratings at ages 14 and 15 were entered as covariates. There was a significant main effect of inattention, F(2, 1,169) = 5.01, p < .01, such that participants with high inattention reported poorer peer relationships than participants with moderate or low levels of inattention did. There was also a significant main effect of gender, F(1, 1,169) = 15.17, p < .001, such that males reported poorer peer relationships than females did. The interaction between inattention and gender was not significant. When covariates were examined, depression F(1, 1,169) = 24.97, p < .001, and anxiety, F(1, 1,169) = 6.61, p = .01, ratings were significant covariates, but inattention and gender remained significant.

sec.title: Early Inattention as a Predictor of Psychosocial Maladjustmalest
sec.p: To examine whether inattention was an independent predictor of risk, a series of hierarchical regression analyses were conducted. Gender and psychopathology self-reports that had emerged as significant covariates in the previous ANCOVAs were entered at Step 1, and inattention was entered at Step 2 to predict victimization and peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 and later peer relationships at ages 14 and 15. Cohen’s f2 (Cohen, 1988) was calculated as a measure of effect size. These results are displayed in Table 3.

caption.p: Hierarchical Regression Analyses With Gender and Psychopathology Ratings Entered at Step 1 and Inattention Entered at Step 2 as Predictors of Victimization at Ages 10 and 11, Peer Relationships at Ages 10 and 11, and Peer Relationships at Ages 14 and 15

tr.td: Dependent measure: Victimization at ages 10 and 11 (N = 1,432)
Dependent measure: Peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 (N = 1,497)
Dependent measure: Peer relationships at ages 14 and 15 (N = 1,130)

sec.title: Inattention predicting victimization
sec.p: Inattention remained a unique predictor of victimization after accounting for gender, depression, conduct problems, and anxiety, which were also entered as significant predictors. For example, higher self-reported inattention was a predictor of greater self-reported victimization, even after other behavioral ratings were statistically controlled.

sec.title: Inattention predicting peer relationships at ages 10 and 11
sec.p: Gender and behavioral ratings (depression and conduct-problem ratings) that had emerged as significant covariates in the ANCOVAs were entered at Step 1, and inattention was entered at Step 2 in a hierarchical regression. Inattention remained a unique predictor of peer relationships at ages 10 and 11, after gender, depression, and conduct-problem ratings were entered, each of which entered as significant covariates. This analysis suggests that more inattention was associated with better peer relationships, even after controlling for other behavioral ratings.

sec.title: Inattention predicting peer relationships longitudinally
sec.p: A longitudinal regression was conducted to examine inattention at ages 10 and 11 as a risk factor for peer relationships at ages 14 and 15. In this analysis, gender, depression, conduct problems, and peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 were entered first, and inattention was entered as the second step to predict peer relationships at ages 14 and 15. Inattention at ages 10 and 11 was a significant predictor of peer relationships at ages 14 and 15, even after controlling for the other variables entered. Peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 and depression were also significant predictors, but gender and conduct-disorder ratings were not. These results indicate that self-reported inattention was a robust and unique predictor of peer relationships longitudinally, even after controlling for other self-report behavioral ratings. The correlation between self-reported inattention at ages 10 and 11 and ages 14 and 15 was r(1,136) = .31, p < .01.

sec.title: Comparing Self- and Parent Report of Inattention in Males and Females
sec.p: Correlational analyses indicated significant associations between parent and self-reports of inattention. The correlation between self- and parent-reported inattention for the total sample was r(1,520) = .31, p < .01. The correlation between self- and parent-reported inattention for males was r(727) = .30, p < .001, and the correlation between self- and parent-reported inattention for females was r(793) = .28, p < .001. Using the test of the difference between two independent correlation coefficients (Preacher, 2002), the correlations between males and females did not differ significantly, p = .67.

sec.title: Self-Report of Hyperactivity- Impulsivity, Depression, Anxiety, and Conduct-Problem Ratings
sec.p: Means and standard deviations for the other self-reported behavioral ratings in the overall sample were as follows: hyperactivity-impulsivity (M = 1.57, SD = 0.45), depression (M = 1.33, SD = 0.60), anxiety (M = 1.54, SD = 0.47), and conduct problems (M = 1.04, SD = 0.24). In the overall sample, there was a large positive correlation between self-reported inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity, r(1,437) = .57, p < .01. Significant positive correlations were also found between self-reported inattention and depression, r(1,437) = .39, p < .01; anxiety, r(1,437) = .39, p < .01; and conduct problems, r(1,437) = .39, p < .01, respectively. William’s t statistic (Hittner, May, & Silver, 2003) was used to compare these dependent correlations. The correlation between inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity was significantly different than the inattention–depression correlation, t(1,437) = 7.29, p < .001; the inattention-anxiety correlation, t(1,437) = 7.62, p < .001; and the inattention–conduct problems correlation, t(1,437) = 8.45, p < .001. These findings suggest the significantly higher co-occurrence between inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity than between inattention, depression, and anxiety in a community sample.

sec.title: Gender
sec.p: Means and standard deviations for psychopathology ratings for males were as follows: hyperactivity-impulsivity: M = 1.64, SD = .46; depression: M = 1.45, SD = .42; anxiety: M = 1.50, SD = .47; and conduct problems: M = 1.19, SD = 0.23, and for females, hyperactivity-impulsivity: M = 1.51, SD = 0.42; depression: M = 1.47, SD = 0.43; anxiety: M = 1.57, SD = 0.48; and conduct problems: M = 1.11, SD = 0.18. When examining correlations between self-reported inattention and other behavioral ratings separately for males and females, findings were similar to the overall sample. For both genders, there was a large positive correlation between self-reported inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity and moderate positive correlations between self-reported inattention and depression, anxiety, and conduct-problem ratings. Using the test of the difference between two independent correlation coefficients (Preacher, 2002), none of the comparisons between the correlation of a particular behavioral rating and inattention for males was significantly different from the correlation of the same psychopathology rating and inattention for females. Table 4 displays these correlations.

caption.p: Correlations Between Self-Reported Inattention and Self-Reports of Psychopathology Ratings for Males (n = 689) and for Females (n = 748)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we examined the correlates of self-reported inattention with parent report, associations with other self-report behavioral ratings, and with indices of psychosocial maladjustmalest. Gender differences were also examined. Inattention was found to be a significant and unique predictor of current victimization and current and future quality of peer relationships. Gender did not interact with inattention on either victimization or peer relationships. Self-reported inattention was significantly but modestly associated with parent-reported inattention, supporting the validity of self-report of inattention in 10- and 11-year-olds. Self-reported inattention was also significantly correlated with self-reports of hyperactivity-impulsivity, depression, anxiety, and conduct-problem ratings, with the largest association between inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity ratings.

sec.title: Inattention as a Risk Factor
sec.p: To situate the inattention ratings in the community sample used in this study, the ratings of inattention by the youth and parents suggest relatively low levels of inattention, which is typical in a community sample. Participants in the high-inattention group, according to parent and self-reports, may have been at risk for ADHD; 8% of self-reporters and 11% of parent reporters indicated high inattention, which is comparable to the prevalence rate of ADHD in the population (APA, 2000).

On the basis of the self-report measures, we found that males in particular and participants in the high-inattention group reported more victimization than did females or participants in the low- or moderate-inattention groups. Interestingly, hyperactivity-impulsivity did not emerge as a significant covariate; however, depression, anxiety, and conduct-problem ratings were significant covariates. The main effects of inattention and gender remained significant after covarying for the other behavioral ratings. Self-reported inattention was also found to be a significant predictor of victimization and peer relationships in the regression analyses. Furthermore, self-reported inattention was also a unique predictor of peer relationships 4 years later, even after controlling for the presence of peer relationships at ages 10 and 11 and other behavioral ratings. This finding is consistent with Bellanti et al. (2000), who reported that inattentive children were significantly less well-liked by peers than the nonproblem comparison group. Peer relationships play a critical role in childhood and adolescent developmalest (Rubin, Bukowski, & Parker, 1998; Santrock, 2005) and are important for the developmalest of social competence and socioemotional adjustmalest (Deater-Deckard, 2001; Ladd, 1999). Poor peer relationships have been associated with antisocial behavior, social anxiety, an increased need for malestal health services (Parker & Asher, 1987), and healthy friendships have been found to be important and protective against internalizing and externalizing problems (Brett, Bukowski, Aunola, & Nurmi, 2007). The results of this study support the unique role of self-reported inattention in early adolescence as a predictor of difficulties in peer relationships in later adolescence. The current findings on psychosocial maladjustmalest contribute to an emerging literature highlighting the unique predictive role of inattention as a risk factor for later developmalest. Inattention has been found to be a risk factor for later achievemalest (Frazier, Demaree, & Youngstrom, 2004; Greenfield Spira & Fischel, 2005; Massetti et al., 2008) and developmalest of executive functions (Friedman et al., 2007).

sec.title: Gender and Inattention
sec.p: There was a significant main effect of gender, such that males reported more victimization and poorer peer relationships. There was no gender by inattention interaction, suggesting that both males and females did not report greater peer difficulties on the basis of different levels of inattention. Reporting high inattention was a risk factor for these outcomes, regardless of gender. The overall gender effect may be partly explained by the fact that the measure of victimization may have characterized more overt forms of aggression, which is more typical of male victimization. Females tend to experience more relational and overt forms of aggression (Zalecki & Hinshaw, 2004), such as gossiping and exclusion, which were not captured in the measure of victimization used in this study.

The prevalence of self- and parent-reported inattention was of particular interest in males and females. According to self-reports of inattention, 9% of males and 7% of females fell into the high-inattention group. In contrast, parent-reported inattention resulted in 16% of males and 7% of females meeting criteria for the high-inattention group. This discrepancy between self- and parent report of highly inattentive males are consistent with prevalence characteristics of ADHD (APA, 2000). It has been suggested that males and females are treated differently at home and have differing behavioral expectations (Rucklidge & Tannock, 2001). Males have been reported to exhibit more visible externalizing behaviors (Gershon, 2002), which tend to co-occur highly with inattention (also shown in this study), accounting for the elevated levels of parent-reported inattention in males. Another possible explanation for this difference is that the 10- to 11-year-old boys may be underreporting inattention, suggesting that they may not yet have the same degree of insight into their behavior as compared to girls of same age. This is consistent with findings reported in Schaughency et al. (1994). No gender differences were obtained in self-reported inattention, which is consistent with other studies that have used community-based samples (Rescorla et al., 2007; Schaughency et al., 1994).

sec.title: Self-Report and Inattention in Youth
sec.p: Self-reported inattention was modestly related to parent-reported inattention, both in the overall sample and for males and females separately. This indicates some concurrence between the informants. The sizes of these correlations are consistent with other literature reporting low to moderate correlations (Achenbach, McConaughy, & Howell, 1987; Fischer, Barkley, Fletcher, & Smallish, 1993; Luby et al., 2007; Schaughency et al., 1994). These results suggest that 10- and 11-year-olds have some insight into inattention problems, which gives some validation to commonly used self-report instrumalests for youth (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001; Conners, 2008).

sec.title: Associations With Hyperactivity, Impulsivity, Anxiety, Depression, and Conduct Problems
sec.p: Inattention was most highly correlated with hyperactivity-impulsivity ratings. Correlations between inattention and depression, anxiety, and conduct problem ratings were significantly smaller but were significant. These results are similar to findings by Schaughency et al. (1994). Correlations between inattention and the other behavioral ratings did not differ significantly between males and females. Thus, this finding suggestions that, in this sample, inattention was not more strongly related to depression and anxiety ratings in females than it did with hyperactivity and impulsivity. Notably, this may have been partly attributable to the developmalestal period of preadolescence sampled in this study, as others have suggested that girls with ADHD experience more internalizing symptoms in adolescent samples (Rucklidge & Tannock, 2001).

Some limitations of this work include the limited number of items in the composite ratings, with 3 items for each inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity composite. Although interitem correlations were significant and of adequate size, future work should examine inattention and increase the number of items comprising each rating to more closely reflect the number of symptoms in the DSM-IV-TR (APA, 2000). As parent report was only available at ages 10 and 11, future work should also collect parent report and self-report data longitudinally to examine associations between self- and parent-reported inattention over time.

There have not been many studies examining self-reported inattention uniquely. These findings from a community sample do support the unique role of self-reported inattention that may place youth at risk in their social relationships. This was demonstrated most profoundly in the longitudinal analyses, which indicated that self-reported inattention at 10 to 11 years of age was a unique predictor of peer relationships when participants were between 14 and 15 years of age, even after controlling for peer relationships between the ages 10 and 11 and controlling for other behavioral ratings. This finding has significant implications, as social relationships become increasingly important as youth become adolescents. This study also provides supporting evidence for the diagnosticity of self-reported inattention and other behavioral ratings at ages 10 and 11 years.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.

The current study was supported by a Joseph-Armand Bombardier Canada Graduate Scholarship form the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC) to LC and funding from the LaMarsh Centre for Research on Violence and Conflict Resolution.

The low-inattention group included consistent responding of never/not true on all 3 items or one endorsemalest of sometimes/somewhat true on one of these 3 items. The moderate-inattention group included at least two instances of sometimes/somewhat true of the 3 inattention items. The high-inattention group included at least two endorsemalests of sometimes/somewhat true and one endorsemalest of often/always true on the 3 items, or multiple endorsemalests of often/always true.
